question: On a sunny day, at what time is the shadow of the school's flagpole shortest?

content.source_1: For a vertical object on level ground, its shadow gets shorter as the Sun climbs and is shortest when the Sun reaches its highest altitude that day (local solar noon).
content.source_2: In places that keep standard time year-round and lie near the time zone’s central meridian, local solar noon occurs at about 12:00 p.m. by the clock.
content.source_3: The school’s region keeps standard time year-round and is close to its time zone’s central meridian.
content.source_4: Daylight saving time shifts civil clocks one hour ahead of solar time; during DST the Sun’s daily transit (local solar noon) reads about one hour later on the clock.
content.source_5: The school is about 10 degrees west of its time zone’s central meridian and the region observes daylight saving time during the sunny months.
content.source_6: Each degree of longitude corresponds to about 4 minutes of solar-time offset; being 10 degrees west delays local solar noon by roughly 40 minutes on standard time, and with DST it appears near 1:40 p.m. by the clock.
